title.narrative: Food Shelter for War-Affected Families in Yemen

description.narrative:
More than two and a half years since the escalation of the conflict, Yemeni people continue to bear the brunt of ongoing hostilities and severe economic decline. People are increasingly exhausting their coping mechanisms, and as a result the humanitarian crisis remains extremely widespread: of the 29 million Yemini, an estimated 22.2 million people in Yemen need some kind of humanitarian or protection assistance, including 11.3 million who are in acute need – an increase of more than one million people in acute need since June 2017.
The devastating conflict has left children and families in urgent need of food, water and medical supplies. According to Unicef, since the conflict began, an average of six children have been killed or maimed every day. Right now more than 11 million children in Yemen are in danger. Malnutrition is at an all-time high. Hundreds of thousands of children are suffering from severe malnutrition and urgently need life-saving food to survive. At least one child dies every 10 minutes in Yemen from malnutrition and preventable diseases!

The life-saving protection and assistance needs of conflict affected internally displaced persons and their host community are met; Ensure continued and regular access to food, shelter and WASH for conflict affected IDPs and their host community.

participating-org.narrative: Yamaan Foundation for Health and Social Development

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Availability of, access to and consumption of food
FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: SHL-I1: Number of people having access to basic, safe and dignified shelters solutions

description.narrative: Basic, safe and dignified: - affected individuals have an minimum covered floor area of 3.5m2 per person. - all shelter solutions and materials meet locally agreed technical and performance standards and are culturally acceptable. - all household (re-)construction is in accordance with safe building practices and standards. - all household (re-)construction demonstrate involvement of the affected population and/or are culturally acceptable by the affected population.

title.narrative: WSH-I6: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

title.narrative: SHL-I4: Number of people provided with non-food items (other than hygiene/dignity kits)

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

title.narrative: FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: SHL-I4: Number of people provided with non-food items (other than hygiene/dignity kits)

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

Number of people who benefitted directly or indirectly with life-saving humanitarian assistance and/or resilient recovery services and/or disaster preparedness from activities in a humanitarian response implemented by Cordaid and implementing partners
